main event: An unidentified object was observed in the sky near Clarendon, Texas on April 18, 1950 by experienced observers, including a Senior-Pilot Corps Pilot and seasoned graduates from respected institutions.
interesting points: The object was sighted at an altitude of approximately 20,000 feet and was initially observed intermittently reflecting sunlight on what appeared to be a metallic surface.
Upon further observation, the object appeared to be silvery metallic with a translucent quality, resembling a sphere-like shape with prominent indentations or hatches.
The object was estimated to be approximately half the size of a full moon when viewed directly overhead, and it displayed no rapid movement or visible means of propulsion.
Despite attempts to establish definite position and identify the object as a weather balloon, the nature of the object could not be definitively determined.
The observation triggered communication with CAA offices, the 8730th air squadron, and involved a descent due to oxygen supply depletion, indicating the seriousness of the sighting.
sighted object: unidentified metallic object with a translucent quality
witnesses: experienced observers, including a Senior-Pilot Corps Pilot
